comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Just because they are well dressed, it doesn't mean they are trustworthy gentlemen. They might be members of the "Swell Mob" (a true tale of daylight robbery involving Inspector Barefoot of B division, a small boy and a £30 note).

Brava Mrs Wells for "collaring" Swell Thompson, and Inspector Barefoot?! Were your Couple of Swells sent to Australia?

comment._content: thx

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: What's the purpose of that spiky railing in the background?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Unveiled 21st April 1868 by the Prince of Wales -145 years ago tomorrow.

comment.author: 93076316@N00
comment._content: It's a pity that nowadays the statue remains inaccessible behind a fence.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Those railings are intended to discourage public urination in what otherwise might be an inviting corner. They tend to be fairly common in cities like London and Paris. Even the hallowed courtyards of Trinity wouldn't be immune from any "swells" caught-short on the way back to their halls of residence.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Thank you. That hadn't occurred to me.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Talking about urination - the statue and plinth looks very fresh, unchipped, and free of Evidence of Dog. So nearer 1868 than 1883? Fred and Judy 'A Couple of Swells' 4'33" digression

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] No worries. I suppose they would more properly be described as general loitering deterrents - rather than anti-urination specifically. But they're not a million miles away from the human equivalent of those "anti roosting" bird spikes you see around. Those particular examples are gone, but there are others around Dublin. There's even a remaining example across the road.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Happy Birthday, Edmund Burke's statue (for he's a jolly good fellow)! How's that for serendipity?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: That shadow is interesting. The sun is low and almost due west. The sun sets exactly in the West in mid March or late September.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The neighbouring image, STP_1258 include Beardy, the statue, and "flags etc." in Grafton street.

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: The Irish admire lots of skills but none so much as the ability to talk. Edmund Burke was regarded as one of the greatest orators of his time.  Looking at the shadow on the wall ,I'm sure somebody could pinpoint the time of day if they had the exact date.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Another great picture from NLI that just begs comment.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here's a delightful coincidence - State Records NSW has just posted a c.1866 photo showing Burke's cousin, Sir Richard Bourke, Governor of NSW (1777-1875, b. Dublin, died Thornfield, Co. Limerick). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bourke Contemporary 140 year-old photos of cousin's statues on the opposite sides of the world - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8676267105/]

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Coincidental indeed :) (Following on from my "drank there" Edinburgh brag, the domain was always a favoured lunch spot in Sydney. When last back I followed the directions of this sign and had a nice picnic with the missus under a tree behind that statue. (Round the back o'Bourke... :) )

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That's a hoot!

comment._content: The Burke / Bourke Statues Limerick There once was a statue of Burke And one of his young cousin Bourke Disagreed how it spells, A fine couple of swells, Or was it a couple of berks?

comment._content: I pay salute for people who had the ability to build such a fine statue at the time....
